newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Yugo planning more liberal foreign trade-minister.
newsitem.headline: Yugo planning more liberal foreign trade-minister.

text.p: Yugoslavia, struggling for admittance to the World Trade Organisation (WTO), plans further liberalisation of its foreign trade regime, a senior government offical said on Wednesday.
"We hope to have a completely liberalised foreign trade regime as envisaged by the WTO in three years time," Yugoslav trade minister Djordje Siradovic said.
"We are preparing a proposal which would provide an even more liberal foreign trade regime than the one we have now," he told Reuters.
Siradovic said the ministry issued some 40,000 import licences in 1996. The share of imports regulated by quotas was cut to 11 percent last year from an earlier 25 percent.
"Exports are even more liberal as only up to seven percent of goods exported last year were on a quota regime."
Yugoslav exports stood at $1.48 billion and imports at $4.1 billion in 1996.
Comparable figures for the previous year are not available due to 1992-1996 war-related international sanctions imposed on the new federation, comprising Serbia and Montenegro.
